authors. Graphical abstract Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology has been widely used for the removal of NOx from flue gas. However, it is still a challenge to develop novel low-temperature catalysts for SCR of NOx, especially at temperatures below 200°C. This paper reviewed the recent progress on the Mn-based catalysts for low-temperature SCR de-NOx with NH3. Catalysts were divided into four categories, single MnOx, Mn-based multi-metal oxide, Mn-based multi-metal oxide with support, and Mn-based monolith catalyst. In the section of single MnOx, the effects of several factors, such as Mn oxidation state, crystallization state, specific surface area and morphology on catalytic activity were systematically reviewed. In the section of multi-metal oxide catalysts, the various roles played by the components of catalysts were intentionally summarized from four aspects, improving de-NOx efficiency, enhancing N2 selectivity, improving resistance to SO2 and H2O, extending operation temperature window, respectively. Moreover, the newly emerging morphology-dependent nanocatalysts were highlighted at the end of this section. In the introduction of supported metal oxide catalysts, the effects of supports were systematically analyzed according to their types, such as Al2O3, TiO2, carbon materials, etc. Considering the actual operation, Mn-based monolith catalysts were also introduced with regard to monolith supports, such as ceramics, metal wire mesh, etc. Subsequently, NH3-SCR mechanisms at low temperature, including E-R and L-H mechanisms, were discussed. At last, the perspective and the future direction of low-temperature SCR of NOx were proposed. Keywords Selective catalytic reduction Low temperature Manganese oxide de-NOx 1 Introduction Nitric oxides (NOx, including NO and NO2) are one of the major air pollutants. They cause serious environmental issues, including acid rain, photochemical smog, ozone depletion and greenhouse effects. The NOx emission accelerates the formation of secondary aerosol and fine particles like PM 2.5. The major source of NOx emission is stationary oil and coal-fired furnaces and diesel engines. Despite increased effort worldwide in fighting NOx emission, it is still showing a rising trend, and tens of million tons of NOx are released into the atmosphere every year. The combustion control and post-combustion treatment are two methods which have been developed to fight the NOx emission. By altering and modifying the combustion conditions, such as fuel reburning, flue gas recirculation (FGR) and low NOx burners, the amount of NOx produced during combustion can be effectively reduced. Among the post-combustion technologies, selective catalytic reduction (SCR) with NH3 as the reducer has been demonstrated to be the most effective and adapted as a preferred method worldwide for the treatment of flue gases from stationary oil and coal-fired power plant. NH3-SCR is a process in which NH3 reacts selectively with NOx over catalyst surface to produce N2 and H2O without consuming excess O2 [1]. Apart from NH3, the urea is the reductant choice for the treatment of NOx emission from mobile sources, such as diesel-powered cars and trucks owing to its compact nature [2–4]. In addition to NOx, the flue gas also contains considerable amounts of sulfur dioxide (SO2), water vapor (H2O) and fine dusts even after the desulphurization and electrostatic dust precipitation [5,6]. Currently, TiO2 supported V2O5, modified by WO3 or MoO3 is the prevalent SCR catalyst in industry [1]. The optimal working temperature for this catalyst is in the range of 300–400°C. Undesirably, to meet this temperature condition without external heating, the catalyst has to be installed upstream before the particulate collector and desulfurization unit [7,8]. As a result from this upstream installation, the catalyst is easy to be deactivated due to particulates accumulation on the surface of catalyst and sulfur chemical poison. Two methods can be used to solve these problems. One is to install the catalyst downstream of the particulate collector and desulfurization unit, which requires an additional heat source to heat the flue gas. The second is to develop novel low-temperature catalysts (LTC) that can work well around 250°C or even lower temperature. It is obvious that the latter is preferred because of economics. To date, numerous studies have been carried out worldwide to develop the low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts and great progress has been made [9,10]. Based on active component, SCR catalysts can be divided into three categories: noble metal (Pt, Pd, Ag, etc.) catalysts, transition metal (Mn, Fe, V, Cu, Cr, Co, etc.) oxide catalysts, and transition metal ion (especially, Cu and Fe) exchanged zeolite catalysts. The noble metals have excellent catalytic activity at low temperature [11], but they are too costly, with a narrow operation window and sensitive to SO2 as well. Therefore great efforts have been directed to the development of transition metal oxide catalysts and great progress has been made [12–15]. Among the transition metal oxide catalysts, manganese oxide-based (Mn-based) catalysts, such as pure nano-MnOx, Mn-based metal oxide mixture, including MnOx CeO2, MnOx FeOx, etc, and MnOx loaded on various supports, including Al2O3, TiO2, carbon materials, ceramic monolith, etc., have shown outstanding low-temperature SCR activity. Despite the extensive reports on material properties and detailed SCR reaction mechanisms of LTC catalyst, there are no review articles focused on Mn-based catalysts. A review in 2011 by Li et al. focused on SCR performances of Mn-based metal oxide and Fe, Cu exchanged zeolite catalysts [12]. A recent review by Shan and Song [13] summarized the catalysts for low-temperature SCR, and large portion of the review is devoted to carbon supported V2O5 and Cu-containing small pore zeolites. A review by Fu et al. [14] focused on the reaction mechanisms and kinetics of NOx reduction on supported MnOx catalysts. In this review, we focused on Mn-based SCR catalysts with attempt to provide an update on recent development. Catalysts were introduced by the following four categories, single MnOx catalyst, Mn-based multi-metal oxide mixture catalyst, Mn-based supported catalyst and Mn-based monolith catalyst. Special attention has been paid to clarify the various roles played by each component in the catalysts, which is a novel angle to understand and gain insights of the catalyst performances. The reaction mechanism over Mn-based catalysts and the future direction for low-temperature NH3-SCR catalysts were also discussed. 2 Catalysts 2.1 Single manganese oxides MnOx has been proven to have a terrific de-NOx potential at low temperatures. It has been shown that the main factors influencing the catalytic activity of MnOx are the Mn oxidation state, crystallinity, specific surface area and its morphology [16–22]. All these factors are correlated to the performance to some extent. Mn is a multivalent element. It forms several stable oxides. Kapteijn et al. [23] reported that SCR activity of Mn oxides decreased in order of MnO2 >Mn5O8 >Mn2O3 >Mn3O4 >MnO, and MnO2 exhibited the highest activity per unit surface area. The activity order was correlated with the onset temperature of reduction as determined by temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments. The descendent order suggested that the amount of surface-active oxygen decreased with the change of Mn valence from Mn4+ in MnO2 to Mn2+ in MnO, which is related to NOx reduction activity. However, Mn2O3 was preferred for SCR reaction due to its high selectivity towards N2 formation. Several other studies also reported that Mn2O3 was more active than Mn3O4 for direct catalytic decomposition of both NO and N2O due to a higher oxygen lability on Mn2O3 [24,25]. Tang et al. [22] reported that both the NO conversion rate and the N2O selectivity were much higher over β-MnO2 than the corresponding values over α-Mn2O3. Compared with α-Mn2O3, β-MnO2 with lower Mn-O bond energy can cleave more NH bonds under NH3 to form more N-species, resulting in higher selectivity to N2O. The crystallinity is another major factor affecting the de-NOx performance. The crystallinity of MnOx is closely related to the preparation methods and calcination treatment. Tang et al. [17] found that the amorphous MnOx prepared by solid phase reaction (SP) and co-precipitation (CP) methods exhibited higher activity at low temperatures in comparison with the highly crystallized MnOx prepared by citric acid (CA) method. Moreover, they found that part of MnOx prepared by rheological phase reaction (RP) after calcination at 350°C turned into an amorphous phase, and MnOx with amorphous phase could promote proton insertion and releasing, resulting in atoms in the bulk to participate chemical adsorption/desorption or redox reaction in addition to surface atoms, hence leading to high SCR activities [18]. Larger specific surface area implies more active sites exposed on the surface of catalyst and more contact opportunities with gas molecules, which can promote the SCR activity. Kang et al. [18] investigated the effects of calcination temperature and precipitant on the de-NOx performance over MnOx. The results showed the MnOx prepared by CP method with sodium carbonate as the precipitant exhibited the relatively higher activity. The large specific surface area (173.3m2/g), framework structure and composition may contribute to its performance. Besides, the morphology of nano-MnOx can also affect the catalytic performance. Tian et al. [20] compared the low-temperature de-NOx performance over MnO2 nanotubes, nanorods and nanoparticles, and found that MnO2 nanorods obtained the highest de-NOx efficiency (above 90%) at temperature of 250–300°C due to the excellent NH3 adsorbability. However, the relationship between the atomic structure of MnOx surface and the catalytic activity need to be further clarified. As we all know, the atomic structure of MnOx surface is very correlative with its morphology. Recently, Hu et al. [26] successfully synthesized a layered birnessite-type MnO2 assembled hierarchical nanostructure, but they did not research its catalytic activity for SCR de-NOx. In fact, these factors influencing the catalytic activity of MnOx are interconnected and correlated under certain conditions. For example, MnOx with amorphous phase usually has higher specific surface in comparison with highly crystallized MnOx, and MnOx with porous structure (morphology) usually has higher specific surface than crystal MnOx particle. Up to now, it is still hard to make sure that which factor plays a dominant role over the others. As we know, the crystallization state, the specific surface area and the morphology are physical properties of catalysts. Comparatively speaking, chemical properties of catalysts are more close to the revelation of the nature of catalytic performance. However, the research on surface chemical process occurred in the SCR de-NOx over catalysts is still on the way. With the progress of analytical methods, the in-situ technologies, such as in-situ DRIFT, in-situ Raman are undergoing to reveal the adsorption state of reactants (NH3, NO, H2O, O2, SO2, etc) on the surface of catalysts, monitor the reaction process, and capture the reaction information. By using these advanced analytical technologies, more appropriate factors dominating the catalytic performance of MnOx are promising to be revealed in the future. Despite single MnOx catalysts present impressive activity at low temperatures, several problems, including poor resistance to SO2 and H2O, high selectivity to N2O at higher temperatures, still need to be overcome for practical application. One of the solutions is to synthesize multi-metal oxide catalysts by mixing or doping MnOx with other oxides. 2.2 Multi-metal oxide catalysts The multi-metal oxides by mixing or doping MnOx with other metal oxides can improve the catalytic properties of single MnOx catalysts due to the synergistic effects resulted from their complementary advantages. It has been demonstrated that several catalytic properties, such as de-NOx efficiency, N2 selectivity, SO2 and/or H2O resistance, operation temperature window, etc., can be modified by mixing or doping MnOx with other metal oxides. The modification can be attributed to the synergistic effects resulted from both electronic and structural influences among multi-metal oxides. 2.2.1 Improving the de-NOx efficiency The de-NOx efficiency of MnOx can be effectively enhanced by doping with another metal element, like Ce, Fe, Nb, Sn, etc. As an abundant oxygen reservoir, CeO2 can be used both as MnOx support and dopant. The redox shift between Ce4+ and Ce3+ leads to the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which greatly enhances the oxidation of NO to NO2 even at low temperatures due to the surface chemisorbed oxygen [27,28]. In addition, the incorporation of Mn ions into CeO2 lattice can also lead to the formation of nano-structured solid solution [29]. Among numerous influential factors, the molar ratio of Mn and the doped metal has been found to be critical to the dispersion of Mn species and catalyst structure [30,31]. The molar ratio determines the proper oxidation state of Mn species and the exact surface morphology, which directly affect the catalytic activity. The low-temperature de-NOx efficiency of MnOx CeO2 catalyst can be further improved by a third metal dopant. For example, Chang et al. [32,33] investigated the SCR performance over Cr, In, W, Ge, Sn and Fe modified MnOx CeO2, and found that catalyst modified by Sn exhibited the highest activity with more than 97% NOx conversion at 80°C. Zhang et al. [34] found that MnOx CeO2 catalyst containing 10% WO3 showed the highest NO conversion in a wide temperature range of 162–374°C. Xiong et al. [35] also showed that the introduction of Ti increased the de-NOx efficiency over a Mn/CeO2 catalyst with more than 90% NO conversion at temperatures of 175–300°C under a gas velocity of 60,000mLg−1 h−1. Besides CeO2, iron oxides (FeOx) are also considered as an ideal additive to promote the de-NOx efficiency [36,37]. Yang et al. [38] found that Fe-Mn-based transition metal oxides were efficient sorbents for NOx removal at ambient temperature. The superior NOx capacity of Fe-Mn-Ti and Fe-Mn-Zr oxides was probably due to the large surface area and high activity of the oxides in NO oxidation to NO2. However, the SCR activity at low temperature decreased by: Fe–Mn>Fe–Mn–Zr>Fe–Mn–Ti, indicating that the SCR activity did not have a correlation with the surface area [39]. Chen et al. [40] found a novel spinel Fe3Mn3O8 phase as the active center formed in Fe-Mn oxides prepared by citric acid method. The NO oxidation was greatly enhanced in redox cycle due to the existence of high redox potential pairs of Fe and Mn. Nearly 100% NOx conversion was obtained at 120°C at a space velocity of 30,000h−1 (Fig. 1 ). Moreover, the initial SCR activity of Fe(0.4)–MnOx (CA-500) was very high (100% NOx conversion) and remained at 74.5% with 95.8% N2 selectivity after 500h of continuous lifetime (Fig. 2 ). Many other transition metals were also studied as a dopant to improve the de-NOx efficiency of MnOx. It was found that Nb could greatly enhance the catalyst surface acidity thus promote the adsorption of NH3. Casapu et al. [41] found that the strong interaction between Mn and Nb species ensured a very good distribution of the oxidizing and acidic sites in the catalyst structure. A clear higher activity was obtained with the Nb-doped catalysts compared with MnOx CeO2 reference (Fig. 3 ). 2.2.2 Enhancing N2 selectivity N2 selectivity is another important indicator for de-NOx performance evaluation. In the process of SCR de-NOx, some side reactions such as the oxidation of ammonia, decomposition of nitrate and ammonium species at high temperatures can lead to partial formation of N2O, which greatly decreases N2 selectivity. Up to now, the intrinsic formation mechanism is not fully understood yet. Some researchers considered that N2O formation occurred especially on well-ordered MnOx crystalline phase due to the presence of highly reactive oxygen [16–18], while the other scientists found that the higher N2O selection resulted from the growing temperature and Mn content in the catalyst [19]. Despite the indistinct formation mechanism of N2O, numerous studies have proved that the addition of other metal dopants can vastly improve N2 selectivity. Qi and Yang [30] studied the effect of the third metal oxides on the activity of MnOx CeO2 calcined at 500°C, and found that the addition of Fe and Zr oxides not only enhanced the activity but also increased the N2 selectivity, while the addition of Pr oxide increased the N2 selectivity but decreased the NO conversion. Casapu et al. [42] reported that Nb-doped MnOx CeO2 oxides could minimize unselective NH3 oxidation due to the formation of MnNb2O6, which diminished the oxidation ability of the manganese species at high temperatures. N2 selectivity was greatly enhanced from the initial 50% before Nb doping to 96% after the doping at 200°C. The NOx removal activity and N2 selectivity were further conducted over MnNbCe-related fresh and aged catalysts (Fig. 4 ). The combination of MnOx with strong redox capability and NbOx with high acidity simultaneously enhanced its de-NOx performance. Similar results were further confirmed over a series of Mn-Nb catalysts [43]. However, not all metal dopants are favorable to the N2 selectivity. It has been reported that Cu [30] and Cr [44] doped Mn-based catalysts resulted in the decrease of N2 selectivity. The reason may relate to the redox and chemical adsorption capacity of the catalysts. 2.2.3 Improving the resistance to H2O and SO2 2.2.3.1 Improving the resistance to H2O Water vapor can lead to the partially deactivation of catalyst due to the decrease of available active sites. Even flue gas in dry conditions, the catalytic activity can be affected by H2O generated from SCR reactions. The negative effects of H2O are generally classified into two aspects: reversible and irreversible deactivation [45]. The reversible deactivation is generally perceived as the competitive adsorption on the catalyst surface between H2O and reactants, like NH3 and NO. The lessened adsorption of reacting agents can then lead to the decrease of NO conversion. However, the inhibition effect will disappear when temperature rises and the catalyst can be reactivated. The irreversible deactivation is typically related to the formation of additional surface hydroxyls (OH) caused by dissociative adsorption and decomposition of H2O on the catalyst surface. Since hydroxyl can only be pulled off at high temperatures (252–502°C), leading to the irreversible deactivation of catalyst even cutting the H2O off at lower temperatures. Long and Yang [39] proposed that Fe-Mn based transition metal oxides are resistant to water vapor at 140–180°C. They found that some active sites for the SCR reaction at low temperatures were occupied by H2O molecules. However, an eternal alteration to the surface active components did not occur as the inhibition effect became less significant when the reaction temperature was increase. The possible reason was attributed to the existence of highly active and redox potential pairs of Mnn+ and Fen+ preferentially located on the catalyst surface, permitting an efficient active catalyst. Wu et al. [46] also demonstrated that a FeMnTiOx mixed oxide catalyst exhibit excellent H2O durability at 150°C with 3.5% H2O in feed gas. Interestingly, H2O favors the enhancement of N2 selectivity due to the inhibition effect of NH3 oxidation at high temperatures [47,48]. Xiong et al. [49] found that N2O formation over Mn–Fe spinel was completely suppressed by H2O addition (Fig. 5 ). The suppression of the formation and/or decomposition of NH4NO3 into N2O could account for this behavior. Similar result has also been reported by Chen et al. [50], who conducted a water vapor effect investigation on NH3–NO/NO2 SCR performance over fresh and aged MnOx NbOx CeO2 catalysts. 2.2.3.2 Improving the resistance to SO2 Catalyst deactivation induced by SO2 is a serious issue for SCR process because significant amount of SO2 is presented in flue gas, especially from coal-fired furnaces. The effect of SO2 on the activity of low-temperature catalysts mainly results from the formation of certain sulfur-containing species on catalyst surface, which play a dual role to affect the SCR of NO with NH3. On the one hand, the sulfur-containing species can improve the surface acidity, which is helpful for the enhancement of NOx conversation. For example, the decomposition of NH4HSO4 on catalyst surface can act as new acid sites for NH3 adsorption, while ammonium ions can react with NO to avoid the deposition of excess ammonium-sulfate salts [51], which promote the catalytic activity rather than poison. On the other hand, the sulfur-containing species can cover the active sites on catalyst surface, which is the main reason for the deactivation of the low-temperature catalysts. The negative effect of SO2 on the catalytic activity can be divided into two results, reversible and irreversible. The reversible effect can be eliminated and the catalytic activity can be recovered by washing with water and/or acid solution. For the irreversible case, the amount and the size of stable sulfates increase with the increase in reaction time, resulting in irreversible damage on the catalytic activity. In general, reversible effect can be transformed into irreversible damage under given conditions. For example, in the research of deactivation induced by SO2 over Mn-based catalysts, researchers found that ammonium sulfate species block the surface active sites, leading to a reversible deactivation. Subsequently, active phases of the catalysts are sulfated to form stable sulfate species, resulting in an irreversible deactivation [52–55]. Although pure MnOx catalysts show poor SO2 resistance, the addition of transition metals to Mn-based catalysts can effectively enhance its SO2 tolerance. It was reported that Fe is capable to decrease the formation rate of sulfate species [56], while Ce is able to inhibit the formation of ammonia sulfate on catalysts surface [57]. Chen et al. [58] found that the SO2 tolerance and catalytic activity of MnOx could be dramatically enhanced by the introduction of Cr due to the formation of CrMn1.5O4. Zhang et al. [59] found the MnxCo3-xO4 catalyst exhibited decent SO2 tolerance due to its hierarchically porous structure, abundant active sites and strong interaction between Mn and Co oxides. Furthermore, several reports showed that the doping of the third metal, such as Sn [33] and W [60,61], into MnOx CeO2 catalyst can further improve the resistance to SO2 poison. Yu et al. [62] reported a mesoporous MnO2-Fe2O3 CeO2-TiO2 catalyst (MFCT) prepared by sol-gel method, which exhibited higher SO2-poisoning resistance compared with the conventional impregnation method (Fig. 6 ). The improved resistance to SO2 poisoning was demonstrated in a 60h NH3-SCR evaluation in the presence of SO2, and the realized NO conversion was constantly maintained at about 78% (Fig. 7 ). The mesoporous channels existing in the catalyst enabled probably a dynamic balance between the formation and decomposition of ammonium sulfate in SCR reaction, which also implies that the SO2 tolerance can be further improved when catalysts possess porous structure or being loaded on some porous supports. 2.2.4 Extending operation temperature window A wide operation temperature window (TW) is always highly desirable for any catalytic reaction system, which affords flexibility to process design and operation stability. Wu et al. [46] found that a FeMnTiOx mixed oxide prepared by cetyltrimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) assisted co-precipitation method presented a wide operation temperature window. Nearly 100% NO conversion was maintained from 100 to 350°C (TW: 250°C) with more than 80% N2 selectivity from 75 to 200°C under a space velocity of 30,000mLg−1 h−1 contained 500ppm NO (Fig. 8 ). Qiu et al. [63] developed a nanocasting MnCo2O4 catalyst which displayed a performance with nearly 98% NO conversion from 100 to 300°C (TW: 200°C) under a gas flow containing 500ppm NO at a space velocity of 50,000h−1 (Fig. 9 ), and the outstanding activity was attributed to the ordered mesoporous structure and strong interaction of Mn and Co. Kong et al. [64] prepared a MnWOx catalyst which obtained 95% NO conversion in a wide temperature range of 180–350°C (TW: 170°C) under a gas flow containing 500ppm NO at a space velocity of 30,000h−1 (Fig. 10 ). Furthermore, metal dopants, such as Sn [33], Ni [65], have been reported to improve the stability at high temperatures or reduce the onset temperature threshold of Mn-based multi-metal oxide catalysts. The temperature window for 100% NOx conversion was extended to 110–230°C of Sn(0.1)Mn(0.4)CeOx from 200–230°C of Mn(0.4)CeOx (Fig. 11 ). 2.2.5 Morphology-dependent nanocatalysts Recently, the morphology-dependent Mn-based multi-metal oxides attracted great interest. An increasing number of studies reported that the size and shape of a catalyst particle at nanometer scale can affect its catalytic performance by selectively exposing the desired facets, and this phenomenon is called as morphology-dependent nanocatalyst [66]. It has been demonstrated that this type of catalyst has active atoms or domains with desirable surface coordination, which improves its catalytic activity and stability. Zhang et al. [59] reported a hollow porous MnxCo3−xO4 nanocage with a spinel structure derived from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) (Fig. 12 ). The catalyst showed superior catalytic activity and N2 selectivity compared with the MnxCo3−xO4 nanoparticles. The reason can be attributed to the hollow and porous structure, which provided a larger surface area and more active sites to adsorb and activate reaction gases. Their results demonstrated that the hollow porous architectures and well-dispersed active components can effectively enhance the catalyst performance in a wide operating temperature window. Further down to atomic level, controlling the morphology of catalyst particles allows a selective exposure of a large fraction of the reactive facets on which the active sites can be enriched and tuned. Gao et al. [67] found that the CeO2 nanorods and MnOx/ZrO2 CeO2 nanorods predominately exposed {110} and {100} facets, meanwhile the MnOx/ZrO2 CeO2 nanorods obtained higher NO conversion with lower apparent activation energy (25kJmol−1) based on a density functional theory (DFT) analysis compared with the MnOx/ZrO2 CeO2 nanocubes and nanopolyhedra (42 and 43kJmol−1, respectively) (Fig. 13 ). The excellent catalytic activity of MnOx/ZrO2–CeO2 nanorods was ascribed to the Mn4+ species, adsorbed surface oxygen and oxygen vacancies associated with the exposed facets. Similar results are also obtained from the de-NOx evaluations and DFT analysis over MnOx/Ce0.9Zr0.1O2 nanorods [68]. All these positive results indicate that the catalysts with better catalytic performance can be successfully synthesized by rationally designing the shape-selective preparation process. As mentioned above, Mn-based multi-metal oxides as NH3-SCR catalysts have been extensively studied due to their high catalytic activity at low temperatures. Various dopants play different roles to influence the catalytic activity of MnOx. For example, Ce can create oxygen vacancies on the Mn-Ce solid solution [29,31], and Nb-doped MnOx CeO2 oxides can minimize unselective NH3 oxidation due to the formation of new MnNb2O6 [42]. Although it is very sure that the multi-metal oxides by mixing or doping MnOx with other metal oxides can improve the catalytic property of single MnOx due to the synergistic effects resulted from their complementary advantages, it is difficult to conclude which metal dopant is more effective at present due to the lack of comparative performance data. Furthermore, there are several very important questions which are desired to be clarified, such as what is the fundamental reason that the catalytic property of MnOx can be improved by mixing (or doping) with other suitable metal oxides? How do these dopants affect the catalytic activity, N2 selectivity, and operating temperature window in different ways? These questions will be the important research directions of low-temperature SCR of NOx in the future. 2.3 Supported metal oxide catalysts Supports play an important role in catalysis. Proper supports cannot only provide huge surface to disperse the active components and prevent from the formation of big crystalline particles, but also supply the space where the catalytic reactions take place. To date, various materials, such as Al2O3, TiO2, active carbon fibers (ACFs), carbon nanotubes (CNTs), etc., have been explored as the supports for the immobilization of MnOx or Mn-based multi-metal oxide. 2.3.1 Al2O3 as the support High temperature resistance, excellent mechanical property, large specific surface area, and easy shape control make Al2O3 to be an excellent support for the immobilization of Mn-based catalysts [69,70]. Singoredjo et al. [71] first studied the NH3-SCR activity of MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalysts prepared from manganese acetate (MA) and manganese nitrate (MN) as precursors. Results showed that MA induced a better dispersion of MnOx on Al2O3 support, resulting in a higher catalyst activity than the catalyst prepared from MN precursor. Surface acidity of MnOx(MA)/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and adsorption of NH3 and NOx on its surface were later studied by Kapteijn et al. [72]. Cao et al. [73–75] prepared Mn-Ce/γ-Al2O3 catalysts modified by well dispersed Zr, Ag and Fe, and the results showed that the high surface area of γ-Al2O3 was the key to increase the active catalytic sites. One major drawback for Al2O3 is its poor resistance to SO2, which hence limits its application on the treatment of flue gases from stationary burners. 2.3.2 TiO2 as the support Compared with Al2O3, TiO2 is less acidic. As a SCR catalyst support, TiO2 offers excellent dispersion of active components and SO2 resistance as sulfate species can be easily decomposed on TiO2 surface. For Mn-based low-temperature SCR catalysts, TiO2 has been proved to be an ideal candidate support [76–79]. Smirniotis et al. [80] first investigated the effects of different TiO2 phases on the catalytic activity of MnOx/TiO2 catalysts in NH3-SCR reaction, and found that MnOx/TiO2 (Hombikat, anatase) exhibited the highest SCR activity, followed by MnOx/TiO2 (Degussa P25) and then MnOx/TiO2 (Aldrich). Due to the highest specific surface area of TiO2 (Hombikat, anatase), MnOx/TiO2 (Hombikat, anatase) exhibited the supreme Lewis acidity and Mn surface concentration, which significantly enhanced its catalytic activity. Peña et al. [81] later also found that MnOx/TiO2 (Hombikat, anatase) obtained 100% N2 selectivity and complete NO conversion at 120°C. The de-NOx activities of MnOx/TiO2 catalysts are closely related to TiO2 properties, either physical or chemical properties, Mn precursors, preparation methods including thermal treatment, etc. All these factors have significant influence on the structure and performance of catalysts. Jiang et al. [82] reported that MnOx/TiO2 catalyst prepared by sol-gel method with an optimum composition of Mn/Ti (mol/mol) of 0.4 exhibited superior activity to the catalyst prepared by impregnation and co-precipitation method (Fig. 14 ). Li et al. [83] found the SCR activity of MnOx/TiO2 catalyst prepared from manganese nitrate was much higher than the catalyst prepared from manganese acetate at temperature below 200°C. Crystal MnO2 and some Mn-nitrate species were found in the former catalyst, while highly dispersed surface Mn2O3 was found in the latter. Shi et al. [84] also prepared a hierarchically macro-mesoporous MnOx/TiO2 catalyst with highly dispersed MnOx species using Pluronic F127 as pore agent, and the amorphous MnOx on TiO2 surface was beneficial for the low-temperature SCR activity. As Mn-based bimetallic oxide catalysts are more active and selective, the catalytic activities of TiO2 supported Mn-based bimetallic oxide catalysts, such as Mn–Ce/TiO2 [85,86], Mn–Fe/TiO2 [87,88], Mn–Ni/TiO2 [81,89], are also intensively studied and the promotional effects of the doping elements are clearly illustrated as well. Ce can promote the chemisorbed oxygen concentration and surface acidity [86], while Fe can further improve the redox properties [87]. Sb can generate strong Lewis acid sites and has a terrific promotion effect on Na resistance [90], while Ca has been reported to be negative at low doping amount due to the resultant less acid sites and lower NO oxidation ability [91]. Smirniotis et al. [92] systematically investigated the effects of metal-doping (Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Ce and Zr) on the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity of MnOx/TiO2 (anatase) catalyst. The results showed that except Zn-doped and Zr-doped catalysts, all the other metal-doped catalysts showed positive impact on the NO conversion of the MnOx/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. 15 ). The SCR activity at 200°C decreased in sequence of Mn-Ni/TiO2 ≫Mn–Cu/TiO2 >Mn–Fe/TiO2 >Mn–Ce/TiO2 >Mn–Cr/TiO2 ≫Mn–Co/TiO2 ≫Mn–Zn/TiO2 ≌Mn–Zr/TiO2. The dominant MnO2 phase and Lewis acidity seemed to be the reason for the superior activity of the Mn-Ni/TiO2 catalyst. The catalytic performances of Al2O3 and TiO2 supported catalysts have been studied side by side by several groups. Jin et al. [93] synthesized Mn-Ce/TiO2 and Mn-Ce/γ-Al2O3 catalysts under the exactly identical conditions, and found that Mn-Ce/TiO2 showed a superior activity to Mn-Ce/γ-Al2O3 at temperature range of 80–150°C. However, the catalytic performance reversed with continually raising temperature up to 220°C. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) study showed that the surface of Mn-Ce/TiO2 was mainly Lewis acidic, while the surface of Mn-Ce/γ-Al2O3 had more Brønsted acid sites. The main reaction pathways of both catalysts were also different. On the surface of Mn-Ce/TiO2, the reaction followed a typical Eley-Rideal mechanism at low temperature, while the reaction on Mn-Ce/γ-Al2O3 mainly proceeded via reactions between NO2-containing compounds and NH3 species at high temperature. Pan et al. [94] found that the catalytic activity of MnOx CuOx/TiO2 was much higher than that of MnOx CuOx/Al2O3 over a temperature window of 100–250°C. The superior performance may result from the larger surface area and higher redox ability of MnOx CuOx/TiO2. NH3-TPD results revealed that TiO2 was helpful in the formation of Lewis acid sites at high temperature of 550–650°C, while Al2O3 was favorable to the formation of Brønsted acid sites at low temperature of 150–300°C. 2.3.3 Carbon materials as the support Carbon materials, such as activated carbon (AC) and activated carbon fibers (ACFs), are widely used in water purification and air filtration due to high specific surface area and interesting porous structure. NO reduction by using modified AC and/or ACFs has been studied in the past few decades [95,96]. Besides, AC and ACFs are also used as catalyst supports [97–99], especially for precious metal catalysts. Generally, AC needs to be pre-treated by concentrated acid to add oxygen functional groups for the enhancement of NOx and NH3 adsorption before loading other active metal components [100,101]. Valdés-Solís et al. [102–104] prepared C/C (carbon/ceramic) cellular monolith supported VOx and MnOx catalysts with good catalytic activity at 125°C by impregnation method. The support activation increased micropore volume and provided an acidic carbon surface, which further enhanced Mn loading during impregnation procedure. Tang et al. [105] found that adsorption capability of Mn-based monolithic catalyst was greatly enhanced due to the attached AC. More than 90% NOx conversion was achieved over the Mn-based monolithic catalyst at temperature range of 150–250°C. Guo et al. [106] investigated the nature of oxygen groups for NO conversion on coal-based AC catalyst, and found that the promoted activity of AC towards NO reduction was most likely due to the enhancement of NH3 adsorption resulted from the carboxyl, anhydride and phenol groups of AC. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs), a special ordered carbon material, have been reported to be an interesting catalyst support for SCR catalysts because of their unique nanostructure and electronic properties [107–110]. Carbon nanotubes supported MnOx catalysts are superior in adsorption and present interesting properties for the decomposition of NOx species [111,112]. Su et al. [113] found that MnOx confined in the channels of CNTs (Mn-in-CNTs) had better abilities of supplying oxygen and adsorbing NO. The electronic interaction between MnOx and the inner surface of CNTs contributes to higher NH3-SCR activity compared with the catalyst where MnOx was anchored on the outer surface of CNTs (Mn-out-CNTs) (Fig. 16 ). Wang et al. [114] found that the NO conversion was continually improved over a multi-wall CNTs supported MnOx catalyst at first with steadily increasing Mn content (<10wt.%). However, with further Mn addition (10–20wt.%), the de-NOx efficiency then remained constant. Catalyst with 10wt.% manganese and an outer diameter of 60–100nm calcined at 400°C presented the best SCR activity. Moreover, CNTs with smaller outer diameters (<20nm) showed higher N2 selectivity, and the possible reason was reported to be related to the nano-channels formed by graphene layers [115]. Recently, an in-situ facile chemical bath deposition route with poly (sodium 4-styrenesulfonate) assisted reflux and pyridine-thermal method to obtain catalyst with highly-dispersed active components on CNTs was proposed by Zhang et al. [116–118]. Catalysts prepared by adopting this kind of method seem to possess higher chemical adsorbed oxygen (Oα) and superior atomic concentration of reducible species. The novel nanoflaky MnOx on CNTs with a uniform core-shell structure (Fig. 17 ) prepared by the mentioned method exhibited better de-NOx activity and wider operation temperature window compared with the MnOx/CNTs and MnOx/TiO2 catalysts prepared by an impregnation method [119]. The promotional effects of Fe and Ce on MnOx/CNTs catalysts prepared by the above-mentioned method have been studied [120,121]. Zhang et al. [116] found that Mn(25%)Ce(8%)/CNTs catalyst not only showed a high catalytic activity with more than 90% NO conversion at temperature of 200–350°C, but also exhibited excellent SO2 resistance. NO conversion decreased slightly from the initial 97% to 90% when 100ppm SO2 was introduced at 300°C, and then gradually recovered to its initial value and remained unchanged. The stability of ammonium sulfate species was found to be declined significantly on CNTs supported catalysts, and the decomposition temperature was shifted to lower region, which made the removal of ammonium sulfate species easier [122]. Cai et al. [123] designed a multi-shell Fe2O3@MnOx@CNTs catalyst, and found that the Fe2O3 shell could effectively suppress the formation of the surface sulfate species (Fig. 18 ). The combined advantages of the high sulfur resistance of the Fe2O3 shell, the excellent de-NOx performance of the MnO2 layer and the great gas adsorption capacity of the CNTs core resulted in the superior catalytic activity. Since both TiO2 and carbon materials present positive effect on the catalytic activity of MnOx, a mixture composed of TiO2 and carbon materials were used as a support to load MnOx for NH3-SCR evaluation. Lu et al. [124,125] found that the TiO2-graphene (GE) nanocomposite supported MnOx and MnOx CeO2 catalysts exhibited high de-NOx efficiency (up to 99%) and excellent N2 selectivity (>97%) under a space velocity of 67,000h−1. The introduction of GE improved the redox performance by promoting the electron transfer between the different valences of MnOx, and enhanced the H2O resistance due to the hydrophobic groups on GE surface. Another TiO2 coated CNTs supported MnOx CeOx catalyst was successfully prepared [118], and the obtained catalyst exhibit above 90% NO conversion from 225 to 400°C. The maximum NO conversion was increased from 92% without TiO2 coat to 99% after coating with TiO2 (Fig. 19 ). The meso-TiO2 sheaths promoted the specific surface area, as well as the chemisorbed oxygen species and acid amounts and strengths. Despite MnOx/carbon materials present attractive prospect in the SCR de-NOx due to their high catalytic activity resulted from the combined advantages of active metal oxides and the great gas adsorption capacity of carbon materials, carbon materials used as de-NOx catalyst supports are restricted to the laboratory research so far. Many difficulties need to be overcome, such as the oxidation of carbon materials in the presence of O2 at low temperatures, the gasification of carbon materials in the higher temperature range. To make matters worse, these metal oxides anchored on carbon materials are excellent catalysts for carbon oxidation/gasification. Therefore, there is a long way before the practical application of MnOx/carbon materials in SCR de-NOx, especially in the low temperature range. 2.4 Monolith catalysts For a typical synthesis procedure of practical de-NOx catalysts, catalysts are usually loaded on the surface or mixed into the channel walls of ceramic monolith or parallel passage reactors by wash coating, dip coating, impregnation or extrusion treatment [126–128]. Catalyst loaded onto cordierite honeycomb ceramics with multilayer wash coat performed much better in NH3-SCR reaction compared with the single-phase catalyst [129]. However, the traditional coating methods also lead to inhomogeneous deposition of active species due to nanoparticles aggregation, and the low inter-phase heat transfer rate of ceramic honeycombs also results in the accumulation of ammonium salts in the corners of the channels inevitably [130]. In recent years, metal foam and wire mesh as catalyst carriers have aroused much concern for their high porosity, stability, thermal conductivity and mass transfer ability [131–133]. The morphology characteristics and physical properties permit metal foam and wire mesh as novel monolith catalyst supports. Liu et al. [134] reported a MnO2@NiCo2O4 nanowire arrays on Ni foam as high-performance monolith de-NOx catalyst. The catalyst was able to sustain high NO conversion and exhibited superior catalytic cycle stability and good H2O resistance. The composition of hollow NiCo2O4 spinel as the core and MnO2 nanoparticles as the shell layer (Fig. 20 ) not only increased surface area, but also promoted the synergistic catalytic effects between Ni, Co and Mn multiple oxides. Another 3D hierarchical monolith de-NOx catalyst with a flower-like NiFeMn [131] mixed oxides and porous Ni-Mn oxide nanosheets deposited on Ni foam prepared by hydrothermal reaction [132] have also been reported. For Mn-based de-NOx catalysts, Table 1 summarizes the temperature ranges and corresponding activities. It is widely accepted that proper supports cannot only provide huge surface to disperse the active components and prevent from the formation of big crystalline particles, but also supply the space where the catalytic reactions take place. Furthermore, some papers reported that supports can interact with MnOx, such as forming solid solution, to influence the catalytic activity. However, the role of supports played in the enhancement of the catalytic activity for NH3-SCR of NO needs to be further investigated deeply. It can be predicted that the synergistic effects between supports and active components will be a hot research topic in the next few years. 3 NH3-SCR mechanism at low temperature The reaction mechanisms over metal oxide catalysts have been investigated over decades [45,72,135,136]. In order to clarify NH3-SCR mechanism at low temperature, three important issues, the role of O2 in low-temperature SCR, the adsorption of NO, and the activation of NH3 on catalyst, should be introduced at first. 3.1 The role of O2 in low-temperature SCR Kapteijn et al. [72] researched the role of O2 in low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3 over alumina-supported manganese oxide catalysts in detail by in situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy and temperature-programmed reaction and desorption (TPRD). They found that no ammonia oxidation was observed if oxygen was absent, and they proposed that oxygen played several roles: it oxidized the catalyst, favoring NO adsorption; it permited hydrogen abstraction from adsorbed ammonia, thereby activating it for reaction with NO; and it could oxidize gas-phase NO to NO2. Subsequently, Kijlstra et al. [137] further studied the role of O2 in low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3 over the same catalysts, MnOx/Al2O3, based on Kapteijn and co-workers’ results. They found nitrosylic species were formed at Mn3+ sites in the absence of O2, and these nitrosylic compounds were unstable in O2 containing atmospheres. In the presence of O2, five species (linear nitrites, bridged nitrites, monodentate nitrites, bridged nitrates, bidentate nitrates) were observed and the formation of these five species was strongly enhanced by the presence of gas phase O2. The role of O2 was to oxidize NO at the surface rather than in the gas phase. 3.2 The adsorption of NO on catalyst Kijlstra et al. [137] studied the adsorption of NO on MnOx/Al2O3 catalysts by use of TPD (with labeled compounds) and FTIR. Two desorption peaks were observed in their experiment, a broad peak in the low temperature range, centred at 450K (LT-peak), and a strong peak at higher temperature, with a maximum at 645K (HT-peak). They found five species formed on the surface of catalyst after NO adsorption in the presence of O2, and their thermodynamic stabilities increased at the order: linear nitrites, bridged nitrites, monodentate nitrites<bridged nitrates<bidentate nitrates. They believed that the nitrites corresponding to LT-peak could react continuously with adsorbed NH3. In contrast, the nitrates corresponding to HT-peak could exist stably in the conditions of low-temperature SCR of NO with NH3, which occupied a part of active sites, resulting in the decrease of catalytic activity. Subsequently, Marbán et al. [138] further found that adsorbed NO corresponding to LT-peak (monodentate and bridged nitrites) could react with adsorbed NH3, according to Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. The thermally stable NO corresponding to HT-peak (bridged and bidentate nitrates) on the surface of catalyst needed higher temperature to react with NH3, and therefore adsorbed NH3 surrounded only (isolated) by thermally stable NO complexes would only be able to react with NO from the gas phase, according to Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. 3.3 The activation of NH3 on catalyst Generally, there are two kinds of acid sites on the surface of catalyst, Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites. The adsorption of NH3 on catalyst is divided into two categories according to the type of acid sites: one is the NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites, labeled as NH4 +; the other one is the NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, labeled as NH3(a). It has been demonstrated by many publications that NH3(a) is very important for the low-temperature SCR of NO [77,83], while NH4 + plays important role in the SCR of NO at middle temperature [139]. Furthermore, only NH3(a) was detected in the absorption of NH3 on TiO2, indicating the adsorbed sites are not on TiO2 if there is NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites. Smirniotis et al. [80] found the Mn/TiO2 with single NH3(a) (without NH4 +) presented highest catalytic activity for low-temperature SCR of NO. The experimental results of Kijlstra [135,137] also confirmed that the NH3 adsorbed on Lewis acid sites of MnOx was the only active species. 3.4 NH3-SCR mechanism at low temperature over MnOx-based catalysts 3.4.1 Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism For a typical E-R mechanism, researchers suggest that NH3 is first adsorbed to Lewis acid center forming intermediates like NH2 and absorbed NH3, which then react with aerial NO and NO2 forming N2 and H2O. The reaction scheme can be described as follow: (1) NH3 +*⇆NH2 −*+H (2) NH2 −*+NO→N2 +H2O where * represents Lewis acid sites on the surface of catalyst. Kapteijn et al. [23] studied the activity and selectivity of pure MnOx and proposed a model upon which NH3 was progressively dehydrogenated by surface oxygen (Fig. 21 ). Marbán et al. [140,141] also proposed the SCR reactions over carbon-supported Mn3O4 catalyst proceed via an E-R mechanism, in which surface-activated NH3 species reacted with the gas phase NO2, and to a lesser extent NO (Fig. 22 ). 3.4.2 Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism The reactions following L-H mechanism are conducted between two adsorbed species. Due to lower activation energy, L-H mechanism-followed reactions are easier to proceed than E-R mechanism-followed reactions. Marbán et al. [138] proposed an L-H reaction scheme. (3) O2 +2★⇆2★−O (4) NO+★−O⇆★−NO2 (5) NH3 +□⇆□−NH3 (6) □−NH3 +★−O→□−NH2 +★−OH (7) □−NH2 +★−NO2 →N2+ H2O+★−□ (8) 2★−OH⇆H2O+★−O+★ where ★ and □ represent adsorbed sites for NO and NH3 on the surface of catalyst, respectively. Wu et al. [77] also proposed that the SCR de-NOx reaction on the surface of FeOx-MnOx/TiO2 catalyst follows L-H mechanism. They found that the stable bidentate nitrates could also react with adsorbed NH3 resulting in the less stable monodentate nitrates and NH4 +, which could then react with NO to produce N2 and H2O. Similar results have been reported in subsequent studies [142,143]. Qi et al. [30] found that gaseous NH3 molecules adsorbed on the surface of MnOx CeO2 catalyst could form adsorbed NH3, NH2 and OH species. NO was oxidized to NO2, followed by an immediate reaction with adsorbed NH3 to form nitrate and nitrite species, which then could decompose into N2 and H2O. A reaction mechanism of NO with NH3 on the surface of MnOx CeO2 catalyst was proposed as follows: (9) O2 →2O−* (10) NH3 →NH3 −* (11) NH3 −*+O−*→NH2 −*+OH−* (12) NO+(1/2) O2 →NO2 −* (13) NH2 −*+NO→NH2NO−*→N2 +H2O+* (14) OH−*+NO2 −*→O−*+HNO2 −* (15) NH3 −*+HNO2 −*→NH4NO2 −*→NH2NO−*+H2O→N2 +2H2O+* Kijlstra et al. [137] suggested that Mn3+ location on the surface of MnOx/Al2O3 catalyst was the Lewis acid center, and NH2 − on these sites could react with aerial NO through E-R mechanism and react with activated nitrite intermediate adsorbed on the surface of the catalysts through L-H mechanism. The reaction scheme can be described as follows: (16) O2 +2*⇆2O−* (17) NH3 +*⇆NH3 −* Lewis acid Mn3+ site (18) NO+O−*⇆NOO−* Bridged and monodentate nitrite (19) NOO−*+O*→NO3 −*+* Bidentate nitrate (20) NH3 −*+O−*→NH2 −*+OH−* (21) NH2 −*+NO→N2+ H2O+* E-R mechanism (22) NH2 −*+NOO−*→N2+ H2O+O *+* L-H mechanism (23) 2OH−*⇆H2O+O−*+* The in-situ DRIFT spectrum characterization is a powerful tool to identify the surface intermediate species. Chen et al. [144] proposed that Brønsted acid sites were the active centers for NO removal and monodentate nitrates were the key intermediate in the SCR reaction based on DRIFT results measured over a Ti0.9Mn0.05Fe0.05O2-δ catalyst. At 150°C, both L-H and E-R mechanisms were involved in the SCR reaction but the L-H mechanism dominated the catalytic activity. Others have also used DRIFT to show dual acid types of Lewis acid and Brønsted acid [42,93,145], and dual mechanisms of L-H and E-R [77]. The in-situ DRIFT has been also used in the study of SCR reaction mechanism over catalyst with carbon materials as supports [146]. Yu et al. [147] proposed two possible reaction pathways on the surface of multi-walled CNTs supported MnOx catalyst at 210°C. One was that NOx ad-species could react with NH4 + to form intermediate of NH4N2O4 (a), NH4NO2 (a) or NH4NO3 (a), then decompose to produce N2 and H2O as the final products. The other pathway was that NH3 was initially adsorbed on active site to form NH2, then NH2 reacted with NOx ad-species to produce intermediate NH2NO2 or NH2NO3, which were unstable and would decompose into N2 and H2O (Fig. 23 ). The reaction pathway of the latter could take place as follows: (24) NH3 (g)+H+ →NH4 + (a) (25) NH4 + (a)+N2O4 (a)→NH4N2O4 + (a)→…→N2 (g)+H2O+O (a) (26) NH4 + (a)+NO2 − →NH4NO2 (a)→…→N2 (g)+H2O (27) NH4 + (a) +NO3 − →NH4 NO3 (a)→…→N2 (g)+H2O+O (a) 4 Conclusions and perspective Mn-based multi-metal oxides with or without support as catalysts for SCR of NOx with NH3 have been thoroughly studied in the past decades due to their excellent de-NOx performances at low temperatures. Pure MnOx catalysts are particularly active but with narrow operation window and poor resistance to H2O and especially SO2. The modification of MnOx by doping (or mixing) with other metal oxides (CeO2, FeOx, NiOx, CuOx, WO3, SnO2, etc.) or being loaded onto the surface of supports (Al2O3, TiO2, carbon materials, monolith, etc.) has been proven to be promising to obtain novel catalysts with high activity. The synergistic effects aimed at electronic and structural interactions have become a hot topic in recent years. Despite much progress has been made on Mn-based de-NOx catalysts, more researches still need to go further and deeper in order to obtain de-NOx catalysts with high activity for actual operation in power stations and industrial heaters. Future researches may refer to the following aspects: 1) The exploration of novel Mn-based catalysts with high combination property, such as high de-NOx efficiency, high N2 selectivity, excellent resistance to SO2 and H2O, wide operation temperature window, etc. The combination property of catalysts directly decides their value for commercialization. However, it is still a big challenge to synthesize catalysts with high combination property. Mixing (or doping) MnOx with other metal oxides and loading Mn-based active components on the surface of suitable supports can be expected to become two promising research directions. 2) The fundamental reason why the catalytic activity of MnOx can be enhanced by mixing (or doping) with other suitable metal oxides needs to be disclosed. A lot of experimental results have demonstrated that mixing (or doping) with other suitable metal oxides can effectively improve the catalytic activity of MnOx for SCR of NO with NH3, and the reasons for this improvement have been attributed to many factors, such as higher specific surface area, more surface defects, more acid sites, higher content of Mn4+ and surface chemisorbed oxygen, etc. The fundamental reason is still unclear. 3) The role of supports played in the enhancement of the catalytic activity for NH3-SCR of NO needs to be further dug out. It has been accepted that supports can provide huge surface to disperse the active components and prevent from the formation of big crystalline particles, and supply the space where the catalytic reactions take place. However, do the supports simply play these roles or do they actually interact with MnOx and alter the intrinsic activity of the active components? How do different supports affect the catalytic performance differently? These questions are desired to get certain answer. Therefore, it can be predicted that the synergistic effects between supports and active components will be a hot research topic in the next few years. 4) The surface chemical process occurred in the SCR de-NOx over catalysts is a very worthy subject to study in-depth. Although the phenomena of the E-R and L-H mechanisms or both of them coexisting in the progress of SCR de-NOx reaction have been demonstrated by many researched results, the NH3-SCR mechanism at low temperature is still not very clear. With the progress of analytical methods, the in-situ technologies, such as in-situ DRIFT, in-situ Raman, along with analog computation, such as MS, DFT [148,149], WASP study, molecule simulations, are undergoing to reveal the adsorption state of reactants (NH3, NO, H2O, O2, SO2, etc) on the surface of catalysts, monitor the reaction process, and capture the reaction information. By using these advanced analytical technologies, more detailed de-NOx mechanisms are promising to be disclosed. 5) The detailed resistance mechanism of SO2 and H2O on Mn-based catalysts is still a big challenge for its application at low temperatures. More efforts need to be made to reveal the suppression effect of SO2 and H2O on the de-NOx activity at low temperatures. Based on the exploration of the surface chemical process, the root cause of the poisoning and deactivation of the catalyst in the presence of SO2 and H2O can be revealed. 6) The development of other non-Mn-based catalysts with high activity at low temperatures. Apart from Mn-based metal oxide catalysts, some other catalysts have also been reported to exhibit excellent low temperature activity. Mixed oxide catalyst, such as Fe2O3/CeO2 [150], CeaTabOx [151], Ce0.65Zr0.35O2 [152], metal oxides supported catalysts, such as CuO/Ti0.95Ce0.05O2 [153], carbon materials supported catalysts, such as V2O5/AC [154], CeO2/CNTs [155], monolith catalysts, such as Fe2O3@CuOx [156], all presented a considerable de-NOx performance at low temperature. Furthermore, their catalytic activities can be improved by further modifying synthesized process. Therefore, these non-Mn-based catalysts have huge potential for obtaining novel de-NOx catalysts with high activity at low temperature. 7) More researches need to be done to apply the catalysts developed from laboratory to practical industry. Indeed, most of the reactivity and mechanistic studies reported in the literature are based on “model” catalysts, and clean conditions (absence of H2O and SO2 in the gas stream) are applied. These “model” samples with compositions are very far from those of commercial catalysts, and the reaction conditions are very far from those corresponding to real industrial application. Therefore, more work need to be done to develop new catalysts suited commercial application, and more studies need to be done to provide new experimental data more directly related to “real” catalyst working under “real” conditions. coredata.dc:description: Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) technology has been widely used for the removal of NOx from flue gas. However, it is still a challenge to develop novel low-temperature catalysts for SCR of NOx, especially at temperatures below 200°C. This paper reviewed the recent progress on the Mn-based catalysts for low-temperature SCR de-NOx with NH3. Catalysts were divided into four categories, single MnOx, Mn-based multi-metal oxide, Mn-based multi-metal oxide with support, and Mn-based monolith catalyst. In the section of single MnOx, the effects of several factors, such as Mn oxidation state, crystallization state, specific surface area and morphology on catalytic activity were systematically reviewed. In the section of multi-metal oxide catalysts, the various roles played by the components of catalysts were intentionally summarized from four aspects, improving de-NOx efficiency, enhancing N2 selectivity, improving resistance to SO2 and H2O, extending operation temperature window, respectively. Moreover, the newly emerging morphology-dependent nanocatalysts were highlighted at the end of this section. In the introduction of supported metal oxide catalysts, the effects of supports were systematically analyzed according to their types, such as Al2O3, TiO2, carbon materials, etc. Considering the actual operation, Mn-based monolith catalysts were also introduced with regard to monolith supports, such as ceramics, metal wire mesh, etc. Subsequently, NH3-SCR mechanisms at low temperature, including E-R and L-H mechanisms, were discussed. At last, the perspective and the future direction of low-temperature SCR of NOx were proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Manganese oxide-based catalysts for low-temperature selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3: A review
